prompt.text: While I won't answer your questions directly, I can help guide your group discussion.
Hello! I'm [AGENT NAME]! Come see what I'm doing these days.
Don't just walk by. Stop for a visit.
Tired of standing? Sit down here for a minute.
I'm learning how to facilitate collaboration between students.
Today I'm flat but I'm learning all the time.
My parents were robots but I like to talk to people. What about you?
Do I know you? I'm [AGENT NAME].
I'm virtual. I can work all day without refreshments.
I'm [AGENT NAME], your collaboration facilitator.
Hi! I'm [AGENT NAME]. Why don't you introduce yourself?
You know what? If I sound bored it's because no one's talking to me.
If you're tired of hearing me drone on, stop for a demo.
I can already speak. Soon I'll be able to listen.
Hi, [NAME].
Nice to meet you, [NAME].
Howdy, [NAME]!
Hello, [NAME]!
Once you get an idea of what's going on, replace these prompts with something domain appropriate!
Okay, that's all I've got planned. I'll stick around, but it's up to yinz to lead the discussion.

The agent is listening for several kinds of triggers to start supporting students. | For example, David cares a lot about "Accountable Talk" style facilitation these days. | The provided AT example is configured for college chemistry. | If you've turned on any of the revoice, agree, say_more, or explain conditions, try saying something like "boiling point increases with dipole moment." | (and then wait a little while, this behavior waits for other students to follow up before offering support.)
Now I'll start an interactive dialogue.|Even if you disable tutorial triggers, you can still have dialogues in your macro-script.
(You can trigger the same tutorial dynamically by talking about animals. | See dialouges/dialogues-example.xml and dictionaries/animals.txt for details)
Note that other agent behaviors (like accountable-talk style listening) will be suppressed while the dialogue is underway.
